figure_1.title: Figure 1.  Press release and news selection.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.  Percentage of press releases containing exaggeration compared to the journal article, for each of the three categories of exaggeration: advice, causal claims from correlational evidence and human inference from non-human samples (light grey bars).
figure_2.caption:
Data from the same analyses by
Sumner
et al. (2014) are presented for comparison (dark grey bars). Error bars are 95% confidence intervals.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.  Percentage of news containing exaggerated advice when the press release was not exaggerated (dark grey bars) or exaggerated (light grey bars).
figure_3.caption:
The data for the same comparison by
Sumner
et al. (2014) are displayed for comparison.

figure_4.title: Figure 4.  Percentage of news containing exaggerated causal claims from correlational evidence when the press release was not exaggerated (dark grey bars) or exaggerated (light grey bars).
figure_4.caption:
The data for the same comparison by
Sumner
et al. (2014) are displayed for comparison.

figure_5.title: Figure 5.  Percentage of news containing exaggerated human inference from non-human samples when the press release was not exaggerated (dark grey bars) or exaggerated (light grey bars).
figure_5.caption:
The data for the same comparison by
Sumner
et al. (2014) are displayed for comparison.

claims.sentence:
The sample was then restricted to those relevant to human health, broadly defined (including all biomedical, lifestyle, public health and psychological topics), that reported on a single, published, peer-reviewed research article (
Figure 1).

See
Figure 2 for a comparison to
Sumner
et al. (2014).

Figure 3 compares this outcome to the data from
Sumner
et al. (2014).

For a comparison of this data to the same analysis from
Sumner
et al. (2014), see
Figure 4.

See
Figure 5 for a comparison of this data to the same analysis by
Sumner
et al. (2014).

Advice
The main difference between the current results and the data of
Sumner
et al. (2014) is that here we found no significant association between exaggerated advice in news and press releases (
Figure 3).

However, the overall rate of exaggeration was lower (outside the 95% CI of Sumner
et al., see
Figure 2).

Figure 1).
